Over-the-Air Federated Learning in MIMO Cloud-RAN Systems

Haoming Ma, Xiaojun Yuan,  Zhi Ding H. Ma and X. Yuan are with the National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Communication, the University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, China (e-mail:hmma@std.uestc.edu.cn; xjyuan@uestc.edu.cn). Z. Ding is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA 95616 USA (e-mail:zding@ucdavis.edu). The corresponding author is Xiaojun Yuan.
Abstract

To address the limitations of traditional over-the-air federated learning (OA-FL) such as limited server coverage and low resource utilization, we propose an OA-FL in MIMO cloud radio access network (MIMO Cloud-RAN) framework, where edge devices upload (or download) model parameters to the cloud server (CS) through access points (APs). Specifically, in every training round, there are three stages: edge aggregation; global aggregation; and model updating and broadcasting. To better utilize the correlation among APs, called inter-AP correlation, we propose modeling the global aggregation stage as a lossy distributed source coding (L-DSC) problem to make analysis from the perspective of rate-distortion theory. We further analyze the performance of the proposed OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework. Based on the analysis, we formulate a communication-learning optimization problem to improve the system performance by considering the inter-AP correlation. To solve this problem, we develop an algorithm by using alternating optimization (AO) and majorization-minimization (MM), which effectively improves the FL learning performance. Furthermore, we propose a practical design that demonstrates the utilization of inter-AP correlation. The numerical results show that the proposed practical design effectively leverages inter-AP correlation, and outperforms other baseline schemes.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, cloud radio access network, multiple-input multiple-output multiple access channel, lossy distributed source coding, over-the-air computation.
††publicationid: pubid: 0000–0000/00$00.00 © 2021 IEEE

I Introduction

With the growing amount of data stored on mobile edge devices, there is an increasing interest in providing artificial intelligence (AI) services, such as computer vision [1] and natural language processing [2], at the wireless edge. Traditional machine learning (ML) methods require uploading local data to a central node for model training, which unfortunately incurs significant communication costs and raises concerns about data privacy. To address these issues, federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising framework for distributed and confidential model training [3]. In the FL framework, each edge device trains its local model using its local data and sends its model update to a cloud server (CS) (referred to as uplink transmission). The CS aggregates the local model updates and updates the global model parameters, and then broadcasts the updated global model to the edge devices (referred to as downlink transmission). Compared to centralized learning, FL significantly reduces the communication burden and the risk of data breaches, and therefore becomes a compelling option for machine learning applications at the wireless edge.

The FL uplink involves transmitting a massive amount of model updates from distributed edge devices to the CS, which poses a critical communication bottleneck due to limited uplink channel resources, such as bandwidth, time, and space[4]. Over-the-air computation has been adopted to improve the communication efficiency of the FL uplink by supporting analog model uploading from massive edge devices [5]. Unlike orthogonal resource allocation among devices to avoid interference, over-the-air FL (OA-FL) enables devices to share radio resources during model uploading by leveraging the signal-superposition property of analog transmission for model aggregation over the air. Pioneering work has confirmed that OA-FL has strong noise tolerance [6] and can reduce latency substantially compared with the FL schemes based on conventional orthogonal multiple access (OMA) protocols. The authors in [7] have further extended over-the-air FL to the multiple input multiple output (MIMO) channel, and leveraged the beamforming technology to enhance the communication quality.

Despite the benefits of OA-FL mentioned above, the limited service coverage of a single CS makes it challenging to access more devices [8]. In general, expanding service coverage by simply replicating CS inevitably results in significant energy consumption, construction investment, site support, leasing, and maintenance costs, making it a costly solution [9]. Additionally, due to user mobility, traffic on each CS experiences fluctuations, commonly known as the ”tide effect.” [8]. These CS must be designed to handle maximum traffic rather than average traffic, resulting in a significant waste of processing resources and power during idle periods.

To address these issues, an effective solution is the MIMO Cloud-RAN architecture. This architecture consists of multiple access points (APs), also known as remote radio heads (RRHs), with each AP serving a specific set of mobile devices. These APs transmit (or receive) signals to (or from) mobile devices through a MIMO-based radio access network and upload (or download) data payloads to (or from) the CS via a fronthaul network [10]. MIMO Cloud-RAN provides flexible network planning and deployment [11], resulting in a significant increase in system coverage at a low cost. Furthermore, it enables the full utilization of idle processing resources and reduces the impact of the tide effect by centralizing computing resources into a resource pool of the CS.

In this paper, we introduce the OA-FL into MIMO Cloud-RAN and proposed a OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework. More specifically, our proposed framework consists of three stages: edge aggregation, in which each AP aggregates local updates from edge devices through the MIMO-based radio access network [7] over the air to generate edge updates; global aggregation, in which the CS aggregates edge updates from APs through the fronthaul network to generate a global update; and model updating and broadcasting, in which the CS updates global model parameters and broadcasts it to every AP through the fronthaul network, which then broadcasts it to their served devices.

Additionaly, we observed that the local updates in FL are typically correlated [12], resulting in correlated edge updates. This correlation, referred to as inter-AP correlation, can be leveraged to significantly reduce the communication cost of global aggregation. To better utilize the inter-AP correlation, we propose modeling the global aggregation stage as a lossy distributed source coding (L-DSC) problem to make analysis from the perspective of rate-distortion theory. Based on this analysis, we further analyze the performance of the proposed OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework. Furthermore, we formulate a communication-learning optimization problem to improve the system performance by considering the inter-AP correlation. To solve this problem, we develop an algorithm by using alternating optimization (AO) and majorization-minimization (MM), which effectively improves the FL learning performance.

Subsequently, we propose a practical design that demonstrates the utilization of inter-AP correlation. Our design includes an encoding function and a joint decoding function, which enable efficient compression and reconstruction of the model updates. Specifically, the encoding function consists of a compression module, quantization module, and error accumulation module, which work together to compress the edge update, add an error accumulation term, and quantize the resulting vector to satisfy the rate constraint. On the other hand, the decoding function utilizes a neural network structure to leverage inter-AP correlation for estimating the global update. The numerical results show that the proposed practical design effectively leverages inter-AP correlation, and outperforms other baseline schemes.

The remainder of this paper is structured as follows. In Section II, we provide an overview of the FL process and MIMO Cloud-RAN. In Section III, we present the OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework. In Section IV, we make analysis for the L-DSC problem and the proposed OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework. In Section V, we formulate an optimization problem for OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN and develop an effective algorithm to solve it. In Section VI, we present a practical design, which exploits the inter-AP correlation. In Section VII, we validate proposed OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN through experiments.

II Preliminaries

II-A Federated Learning

We consider a wireless federated learning (FL) system, where NDsubscript𝑁𝐷N_{D} edge devices and a cloud server (CS) collaboratively learn a shared model based on the training data distributed over the NDsubscript𝑁𝐷N_{D} edge devices. The objective is to minimize a global loss function ℒ​(𝜽)ℒ𝜽\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}), i.e.,

min𝜽⁡ℒ​(𝜽)≜∑k∈[ND]ℒk​(𝜽),≜subscript𝜽ℒ𝜽subscript𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐷subscriptℒ𝑘𝜽\min_{\bm{\theta}}\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta})\triangleq\sum_{k\in\left[N_{D}\right]}\mathcal{L}_{k}(\bm{\theta}), (1)

where vector 𝜽∈ℝN𝜽superscriptℝ𝑁\bm{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{N} is the global model parameter vector with length N𝑁N, and ℒk​(𝜽)subscriptℒ𝑘𝜽\mathcal{L}_{k}(\bm{\theta}) is the empirical loss of device k𝑘k, defined by

ℒk​(𝜽)=∑𝒃∈ℬkl​(𝜽,𝒃),subscriptℒ𝑘𝜽subscript𝒃subscriptℬ𝑘𝑙𝜽𝒃\mathcal{L}_{k}(\bm{\theta})=\sum_{\bm{b}\in\mathcal{B}_{k}}l(\bm{\theta},\bm{b}), (2)

where l​(𝜽,𝒃)𝑙𝜽𝒃l(\bm{\theta},\bm{b}) is the sample-wise loss function, ℬksubscriptℬ𝑘\mathcal{B}_{k} is the local dataset of device k𝑘k, and 𝒃𝒃\bm{b} is a data sample of ℬksubscriptℬ𝑘\mathcal{B}_{k}.

The minimization in (1) is typically solved by gradient descent (GD). Specifically, at each training round t𝑡t, the model parameter 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} is updated via

𝜽(t+1)=𝜽(t)−η​∇𝜽ℒ​(𝜽(t))=𝜽(t)−η​∑k∈[ND]𝒈k(t),superscript𝜽𝑡1superscript𝜽𝑡𝜂subscript∇𝜽ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscript𝜽𝑡𝜂subscript𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐷superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)}=\bm{\theta}^{(t)}-\eta\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t)})=\bm{\theta}^{(t)}-\eta\sum_{k\in[N_{D}]}\bm{g}_{k}^{(t)}, (3)

where η∈ℝ𝜂ℝ\eta\in\mathbb{R} is a predetermined learning rate, and 𝒈k(t)≜∇𝜽ℒk​(𝜽(t))∈ℝN≜superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡subscript∇𝜽subscriptℒ𝑘superscript𝜽𝑡superscriptℝ𝑁\bm{g}_{k}^{(t)}\triangleq\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{k}(\bm{\theta}^{(t)})\in\mathbb{R}^{N} is the local update uploaded from each device k𝑘k to the CS over an uplink channel. After that, 𝜽(t+1)superscript𝜽𝑡1\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)} is broadcast to all the devices by the CS over a downlink channel to synchronize the learning model among the devices. The above process continues until it converges.

II-B MIMO Cloud-RAN

In this paper, we consider the deployment of the above FL over a cloud-computing-based architecture for cellular networks, termed MIMO Cloud-RAN [13]. This architecture consists of multiple access points (APs), also known as remote radio heads (RRHs). Each AP serves an individual set of mobile devices. These APs transmit (or receive) signals to (or from) mobile devices through a MIMO-based radio access network, and uploads (or downloads) the data payload to (or from) the CS via a fronthaul network, as depicted in Fig. 1. Details are given below.

  1. 1.

    Uplink radio access network: The uplink radio access network is a MIMO MAC channel, where each AP is equipped with NRsubscript𝑁𝑅N_{R} antennas, and each terminal device with NTsubscript𝑁𝑇N_{T} antennas. We assume block-fading, i.e., the channel state information (CSI) keeps invariant during a training round. Let C𝐶C be the number of uplink channel uses in a training round. Then the received signal matrix at AP i𝑖i in the t𝑡t-th round is expressed as

Note that the sum in (4) implies that signals {𝑿k(t)}k∈𝒩D,isubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑿𝑘𝑡𝑘subscript𝒩𝐷𝑖\{\bm{X}_{k}^{(t)}\}_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{D,i}} are transmitted over shared radio resources and are synchronized among devices222The synchronization can be realized by using the existing techniques, e.g., the timing-advance mechanism for uplink synchronization in 4G Long Term Evolution (LTE) [16].. This enables the utilization of the superposition characteristic of electromagnetic waves for signal aggregation, a.k.a., over-the-air computation.

  2. 2.

    Uplink fronthaul network: The uplink fronthaul network relies on dedicated fibers for data delivery [10]. Specifically, each AP i𝑖i transmits its signals to the CS via a rate-constrained wired link.

  3. 3.

    Downlink fronthaul network: Similarly, in the downlink fronthaul network, the CS broadcasts its signals to every AP via a rate-constrained wired link.

  4. 4.

    Downlink radio access network: The downlink radio access network associated with each AP i𝑖i is a MIMO broadcast channel, i.e., the downlink dual of the MIMO MAC in (4). In each training round t𝑡t, each AP i𝑖i broadcasts its signals to every device in 𝒩D,isubscript𝒩𝐷𝑖\mathcal{N}_{D,i}.

III OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN

We now describe the FL process deployed in the MIMO Cloud-RAN system. As depicted in Fig. 2, the OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework consists of three stages: (i) edge aggregation; (ii) global aggregation; and (iii) model updating and broadcasting.

III-A Edge Aggregation

We start with the edge aggregation stage of the proposed framework, where each AP aggregates local updates from NDsubscript𝑁𝐷N_{D} devices through the uplink radio access network in an over-the-air fashion. Specifically, at the t𝑡t-th round, each device k𝑘k first normalizes its local update 𝒈k(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\bm{g}_{k}^{(t)} by

III-B Global Aggregation

We now describe the global aggregation stage of our proposed framework, where the CS aggregates edge updates from NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} APs through the uplink fronthaul network. Specifically, at the t𝑡t-th round, each AP i𝑖i encodes 𝒔i(t)superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑡\bm{s}_{i}^{(t)} to a vector

𝒖i(t)=fi(t)​(𝒔i(t))∈[Bi(t)],∀i∈[NA],formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑡delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑡for-all𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐴\bm{u}_{i}^{(t)}=f_{i}^{(t)}\left(\bm{s}_{i}^{(t)}\right)\in[B_{i}^{(t)}],\forall i\in[N_{A}], (11)

where fi(t):ℝN→[Bi(t)],∀i∈[NA]:superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡formulae-sequence→superscriptℝ𝑁delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑡for-all𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐴f_{i}^{(t)}:\mathbb{R}^{N}\rightarrow[B_{i}^{(t)}],\forall i\in[N_{A}] is an encoding function, and Bi(t)superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑡B_{i}^{(t)} is the codebook size of fi(t)superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡f_{i}^{(t)}. Then each AP transmits 𝒖i(t)superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖𝑡\bm{u}_{i}^{(t)} to the CS over the uplink fronthaul network. Upon receiving the signals {𝒖i(t)}i∈[NA]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐴\{\bm{u}_{i}^{(t)}\}_{i\in[N_{A}]}, the CS aggregates (or alternatively, decodes) them as a global update.

𝒛^(t)=f(t)​(𝒖1(t),…,𝒖NA(t))∈ℝN,superscript^𝒛𝑡superscript𝑓𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒖1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝒖subscript𝑁𝐴𝑡superscriptℝ𝑁\hat{\bm{z}}^{(t)}=f^{(t)}\left(\bm{u}_{1}^{(t)},\dots,\bm{u}_{N_{A}}^{(t)}\right)\in\mathbb{R}^{N}, (12)

where f(t):[Bi(t)]×⋯×[BNA(t)]→ℝN:superscript𝑓𝑡→delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑡⋯delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐵subscript𝑁𝐴𝑡superscriptℝ𝑁f^{(t)}:[B_{i}^{(t)}]\times\dots\times[B_{N_{A}}^{(t)}]\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{N} is a decoding function. Local updates in FL are typically correlated [12], resulting in correlated edge updates. This correlation, called inter-AP correlation, can be exploited to significantly reduce the communication cost of global aggregation. To improve communication efficiency, we treat global aggregation as a lossy distributed source coding (L-DSC) process. In L-DSC, given an aggregation target function κ:ℝN×⋯×ℝN⏟NA→ℝN:𝜅→subscript⏟superscriptℝ𝑁⋯superscriptℝ𝑁subscript𝑁𝐴superscriptℝ𝑁\kappa:\underbrace{\mathbb{R}^{N}\times\dots\times\mathbb{R}^{N}}_{N_{A}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{N} and a distortion measure function d:ℝN×ℝN→ℝ+,:𝑑→superscriptℝ𝑁superscriptℝ𝑁subscriptℝd:\mathbb{R}^{N}\times\mathbb{R}^{N}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+}, an achievable rate-distortion tuple is defined below.

Definition 1.

A rate-distortion tuple (R1(t),…,RNA(t),D(t)),∀tsuperscriptsubscript𝑅1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝑅subscript𝑁𝐴𝑡superscript𝐷𝑡for-all𝑡\left(R_{1}^{(t)},\ldots,R_{N_{A}}^{(t)},D^{(t)}\right),\forall t is said to be achievable if for any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 and any sufficiently large N𝑁N, there exists NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} encoding functions {fi(t)}i=1NAsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑡𝑖1subscript𝑁𝐴\left\{f_{i}^{(t)}\right\}_{i=1}^{N_{A}} and a joint decoding function f(t)superscript𝑓𝑡f^{(t)} such that rate 1N​log⁡(Bi(t))≤Ri(t)+ϵ,∀i∈[NA]formulae-sequence1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡italic-ϵfor-all𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐴\frac{1}{N}\log\left(B_{i}^{(t)}\right)\leq R_{i}^{(t)}+\epsilon,\forall i\in[N_{A}], and expected aggregation distortion 1N​𝔼​[d​(𝐳(t),𝐳^(t))]≤D(t)+ϵ1𝑁𝔼delimited-[]𝑑superscript𝐳𝑡superscript^𝐳𝑡superscript𝐷𝑡italic-ϵ\frac{1}{N}\mathbb{E}\left[d\left(\mathbf{z}^{(t)},\hat{\mathbf{z}}^{(t)}\right)\right]\leq D^{(t)}+\epsilon, where 𝐳(t)≜κ​(𝐬1(t),…,𝐬NA(t))≜superscript𝐳𝑡𝜅superscriptsubscript𝐬1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝐬subscript𝑁𝐴𝑡\bm{z}^{(t)}\triangleq\kappa\left(\bm{s}_{1}^{(t)},\dots,\bm{s}_{N_{A}}^{(t)}\right).

The rate-distortion region of L-DSC is defined as the set of all achievable rate-distortion tuples, denoted by ℛ​𝒟(t)ℛsuperscript𝒟𝑡\mathcal{RD}^{(t)}. Detailed analysis of L-DSC will be provided later in Section IV-A.

III-C Model Updating and Broadcasting

We now describe the model updating and broadcasting stage of our proposed framework. Specifically, the CS computes the vector 𝒈^(t)∈ℝNsuperscript^𝒈𝑡superscriptℝ𝑁\hat{\bm{g}}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{N} as

𝒈^(t)=𝒛^(t)+∑k∈[ND]g¯k(t)​𝟏∈ℝN,superscript^𝒈𝑡superscript^𝒛𝑡subscript𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐷superscriptsubscript¯𝑔𝑘𝑡1superscriptℝ𝑁\hat{\bm{g}}^{(t)}=\hat{\bm{z}}^{(t)}+\sum_{k\in\left[N_{D}\right]}\bar{g}_{k}^{(t)}\mathbf{1}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}, (13)

where the bias term ∑k∈[ND]g¯k(t)subscript𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐷superscriptsubscript¯𝑔𝑘𝑡\sum_{k\in[N_{D}]}\bar{g}_{k}^{(t)} given in (5) is known at the CS through error-free transmission. Then the CS updates the global model as

𝜽(t+1)=𝜽(t)−η​𝒈^(t),superscript𝜽𝑡1superscript𝜽𝑡𝜂superscript^𝒈𝑡\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)}=\bm{\theta}^{(t)}-\eta\hat{\bm{g}}^{(t)}, (14)

where η𝜂\eta is given in (3). Then the CS broadcasts the global model 𝜽(t+1)superscript𝜽𝑡1\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)} to every AP via the downlink fronthaul network described in Section II-B. Next each AP i𝑖i broadcasts received 𝜽(t+1)superscript𝜽𝑡1\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)} to every device in 𝒩D,isubscript𝒩𝐷𝑖\mathcal{N}_{D,i}. Following the common practice in [17, 18, 12, 19, 20], we assume that the broadcast process in the downlink fronthaul network and the downlink radio access network is error-free. The overall scheme of OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN is summarized in Algorithm 1.

IV Performance Analysis

In this section, we first analyze the L-DSC problem described in Section III-B, and then carry out the performance analysis of the MIMO Cloud-RAN based OA-FL, yielding an upper bound on the learning performance.

IV-A Preliminaries

Recall that we model global aggregation as an L-DSC process. We define the rate-distortion region ℛ​𝒟(t)ℛsuperscript𝒟𝑡\mathcal{RD}^{(t)} as the set of all achievable rate-distortion tuples in L-DSC at the t𝑡t-th training round. However, this region is generally unknown. To establish a tractable inner region of ℛ​𝒟(t)ℛsuperscript𝒟𝑡\mathcal{RD}^{(t)}, we rely on the following assumptions.

Assumption 1.

Denote a matrix 𝚺S(t)∈ℝNA×NAsuperscriptsubscript𝚺𝑆𝑡superscriptℝsubscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐴\bm{\Sigma}_{S}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{N_{A}\times N_{A}} with [𝚺S(t)]i,j=1N​𝔼​[(𝐬i(t))𝖳​𝐬j(t)],∀i,j∈[NA]formulae-sequencesubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑆𝑡𝑖𝑗1𝑁𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐬𝑖𝑡𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐬𝑗𝑡for-all𝑖𝑗delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐴[\bm{\Sigma}_{S}^{(t)}]_{i,j}=\frac{1}{N}\mathbb{E}\left[(\bm{s}_{i}^{(t)})^{\mathsf{T}}\bm{s}_{j}^{(t)}\right],\forall i,j\in[N_{A}]. Denote the n𝑛n-th entry of 𝐬i(t)superscriptsubscript𝐬𝑖𝑡\bm{s}_{i}^{(t)} as si,n(t)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑛𝑡s_{i,n}^{(t)}. For the edge updates {𝐬i(t)}i∈[NA]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐬𝑖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐴\{\bm{s}_{i}^{(t)}\}_{i\in[N_{A}]}, we assume that (i) si,n(t)∼𝒩​(0,[𝚺S(t)]i,i),∀i∈[NA],∀n∈[N]formulae-sequencesimilar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑛𝑡𝒩0subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑆𝑡𝑖𝑖formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐴for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁s_{i,n}^{(t)}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,[\bm{\Sigma}_{S}^{(t)}]_{i,i}),\forall i\in[N_{A}],\forall n\in[N], and (ii) (s1,n(t)(s_{1,n}^{(t)}, s2,n(t)superscriptsubscript𝑠2𝑛𝑡s_{2,n}^{(t)}, …italic-…\dots, sNA,n(t))∼𝒩(𝟎,𝚺S(t)),∀n∈[N]s_{N_{A},n}^{(t)})\sim\mathcal{N}(\bm{0},\bm{\Sigma}_{S}^{(t)}),\forall n\in[N].

Proof.

See the proof in [20]. ∎

We emphasize that the choice of L-DSC parameter 𝚺V(t)superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝑡\bm{\Sigma}_{V}^{(t)} leads to different codebooks for L-DSC. By tuning the L-DSC parameter 𝚺V(t)superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝑡\bm{\Sigma}_{V}^{(t)}, we search for the rate-distortion tuple in ℛ​𝒟in(t)ℛsuperscriptsubscript𝒟in𝑡\mathcal{R}\mathcal{D}_{\text{in}}^{(t)} that minimizes the distortion 𝔼​[‖𝒛(t)−𝒛^(t)‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝒛𝑡superscriptbold-^𝒛𝑡2\mathbb{E}[\|\bm{z}^{(t)}-\bm{\hat{z}}^{(t)}\|^{2}]. However, due to the link rate-constraints, 𝚺V(t)superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝑡\bm{\Sigma}_{V}^{(t)} cannot be chosen arbitrarily. Let ri(t)superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑡r_{i}^{(t)} denote the maximum information rate that AP i𝑖i can transmit to the CS at the training round t𝑡t. To ensure reliable uplink transmission, the (source coding) rates in Lemma 1 must satisfy

Ri(t)≤ri(t),∀i∈[NA].formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑡for-all𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝐴R_{i}^{(t)}\leq r_{i}^{(t)},\forall i\in[N_{A}]. (16)

IV-C Convergence Analysis of OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN

We now present convergence analysis to establish the relationship between the FL convergence rate and the communication error (17). Following [22], we introduce standard assumptions in stochastic optimization below.

Assumption 2.

(i) ℒ​(⋅)ℒ⋅\mathcal{L}(\cdot) is strongly convex with some (positive) parameter μ𝜇\mu. That is, ℒ​(𝐲)≥ℒ​(𝐱)+(𝐲−𝐱)T​∇ℒ​(𝐱)+μ2​‖𝐲−𝐱‖2,∀𝐱,𝐲∈ℝNformulae-sequenceℒ𝐲ℒ𝐱superscript𝐲𝐱𝑇∇ℒ𝐱𝜇2superscriptnorm𝐲𝐱2for-all𝐱𝐲superscriptℝ𝑁\mathcal{L}(\bm{y})\geq\mathcal{L}(\bm{x})+(\bm{y}-\bm{x})^{T}\nabla\mathcal{L}(\bm{x})+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\bm{y}-\bm{x}\|^{2},\forall\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}. (ii) The gradient ∇ℒ​(⋅)∇ℒ⋅\nabla\mathcal{L}(\cdot) is Lipschitz continuous with some (positive) parameter L𝐿L. That is, ‖∇ℒ​(𝐱)−∇ℒ​(𝐲)‖≤L​‖𝐱−𝐲‖,∀𝐱,𝐲∈ℝNformulae-sequencenorm∇ℒ𝐱∇ℒ𝐲𝐿norm𝐱𝐲for-all𝐱𝐲superscriptℝ𝑁\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(\bm{x})-\nabla\mathcal{L}(\bm{y})\|\leq L\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|,\forall\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}. (iii) ℒ​(⋅)ℒ⋅\mathcal{L}(\cdot) is twice continuously differentiable. (iv) The gradient with respect to any training sample, denoted by ∇l​(𝛉;⋅)∇𝑙𝛉⋅\nabla l(\bm{\theta};\cdot), is upper bounded at 𝛉𝛉\bm{\theta} as ‖∇l​(𝛉,𝐛)‖2≤γ1+γ2​‖∇ℒ​(𝛉)‖2superscriptnorm∇𝑙𝛉𝐛2subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2superscriptnorm∇ℒ𝛉2\left\|\nabla l(\bm{\theta},\bm{b})\right\|^{2}\leq\gamma_{1}+\gamma_{2}\left\|\nabla\mathcal{L}\left(\bm{\theta}\right)\right\|^{2}, where 𝐛𝐛\bm{b} is a data sample from the whole datasets {ℬk}k=1NDsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptℬ𝑘𝑘1subscript𝑁𝐷\{\mathcal{B}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{N_{D}}, and γ1≥0,γ2>0formulae-sequencesubscript𝛾10subscript𝛾20\gamma_{1}\geq 0,\gamma_{2}>0 are some constants.

Assumption 2-(i) ensures that a global optimum exists for the loss function ℒ​(⋅)ℒ⋅\mathcal{L}(\cdot). Assumption 2-(ii) is imposed on the gradient function ∇ℒ​(⋅)∇ℒ⋅\nabla\mathcal{L}(\cdot) to prevent the function value from changing too fast, so as to construct a more robust machine learning model. Assumption 2-(iv) provides a bound on the norm of the local gradients, i.e., 𝒈ksubscript𝒈𝑘\bm{g}_{k}. Assumption 2 leads to an upper bound on the loss function ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)}) with respect to the model updating (14), as given in the following lemma.

Lemma 3.

Assume that ℒ​(⋅)ℒ⋅\mathcal{L}(\cdot) satisfies Assumption 2, at the t𝑡t-th training round with the learning rate η𝜂\eta is set to 1/L1𝐿1/L. Then

𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))]≤𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t))]−12​L​𝔼​[‖∇ℒ​(𝜽(t))‖2]+12​L​𝔼​[‖𝒆(t)‖2],𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡12𝐿𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡212𝐿𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝒆𝑡2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)})]\leq\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t)})]-\frac{1}{2L}\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t)})\|^{2}]+\frac{1}{2L}\mathbb{E}[\|\bm{e}^{(t)}\|^{2}], (20)

where the Lipschitz constant L𝐿L is given in Assumption 2- (ii).

Proof.

See [22, Lemma 2.1]. ∎

We are now ready to present an upper bound of the expected difference between the training loss and the optimal loss at round t+1𝑡1t+1, i.e., 𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))−ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))]𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})].

Theorem 1.

Based on Assumption 2, the loss function at the t𝑡t-th round ℒ​(𝛉)(t)ℒsuperscript𝛉𝑡\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta})^{(t)} satisfies

𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))]−𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))]≤(1−μL)t​(𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(1))]−𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))])+∑t′=1t(1−μL)t−t′​NL​D𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆(t′),𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽1𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑁𝐿superscriptsubscript𝐷𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆superscript𝑡′\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)})]-\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})]\leq\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{t}\left(\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(1)})]-\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})]\right)+\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{t-t^{\prime}}\frac{N}{L}D_{\mathsf{system}}^{(t^{\prime})}, (21)

where (⋅)tsuperscript⋅𝑡(\cdot)^{t} denotes the t𝑡t-th power operator, ℒ​(⋅)ℒ⋅\mathcal{L}(\cdot) is the total empirical loss function given in (1), 𝛉(1)superscript𝛉1\bm{\theta}^{(1)} is the initial system model parameter, and D𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆(t)superscriptsubscript𝐷𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆𝑡D_{\mathsf{system}}^{(t)} is given in Lemma 2.

Proof.

From [22, eq. (2.4)], we have

𝔼​[‖∇ℒ​(𝜽(t))‖2]≥2​μ​(𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t))]−𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))]).𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡22𝜇𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆\mathbb{E}[||\nabla\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t)})||^{2}]\geq 2\mu(\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t)})]-\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})]). (22)

Subtracting 𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))]𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})] on both sides of (20) in Lemma 3 and plugging (22) and Lemma 2 into (20), we obtain

𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))]−𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))]≤(1−μL)​(𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t))]−𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))])+NL​D𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆(t).𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆1𝜇𝐿𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆𝑁𝐿superscriptsubscript𝐷𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆𝑡\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)})]-\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})]\leq\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)\left(\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t)})]-\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})]\right)+\frac{N}{L}D_{\mathsf{system}}^{(t)}. (23)

Applying the above inequality recursively yields (21), which completes the proof. ∎

From Theorem 1, we see that 𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t))−ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))]𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})], i.e., the expected difference between the training loss and the optimal loss at the t𝑡t-th round, is upper bounded by the right-hand side of the inequality in (21). Moreover, this upper bound converges with speed 1−μL1𝜇𝐿1-\frac{\mu}{L}, since μL>0𝜇𝐿0\frac{\mu}{L}>0. Empirically, we find that our proposed scheme always converges with appropriately chosen system parameters. The following corollary further characterizes the convergence behavior of 𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))−ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))]𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})].

Corollary 1.

As t→∞→𝑡t\rightarrow\infty, we have

limt→∞𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))−ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))]≤∑t′=1t(1−μL)t−t′​NL​D𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆(t′)subscript→𝑡𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑁𝐿superscriptsubscript𝐷𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆superscript𝑡′\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})]\leq\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{t-t^{\prime}}\frac{N}{L}D_{\mathsf{system}}^{(t^{\prime})} (24)
Proof.

By noting μL>0𝜇𝐿0\frac{\mu}{L}>0, we have limt→∞(1−μL)t=0subscript→𝑡superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡0\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}(1-\frac{\mu}{L})^{t}=0. Plugging this result into (21), we obtain (24). ∎

Corollary 1 shows that our proposed scheme guarantees to converge. However, there generally exists a gap between the converged loss limt→∞𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))]subscript→𝑡𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)})] and the optimal one 𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))]𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})] because of the communication error. Therefore, we next aim to minimize the gap, so as to optimize our proposed framework.

V System Optimization

V-A Problem Formulation

From Theorem 1 and Corollary 1, the upper bound ∑t′=1t(1−μL)t−t′​NL​D𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆(t′)superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑁𝐿superscriptsubscript𝐷𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆superscript𝑡′\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{t-t^{\prime}}\frac{N}{L}D_{\mathsf{system}}^{(t^{\prime})} in (24) represents the impact of the wireless transmission error and the wired transmission error on the asymptotic learning performance. Specifically, a smaller ∑t′=1t(1−μL)t−t′​NL​D𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆(t′)superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑁𝐿superscriptsubscript𝐷𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆superscript𝑡′\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{t-t^{\prime}}\frac{N}{L}D_{\mathsf{system}}^{(t^{\prime})} leads to a smaller gap in limt→∞𝔼​[ℒ​(𝜽(t+1))−ℒ​(𝜽(⋆))]subscript→𝑡𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝜽𝑡1ℒsuperscript𝜽⋆\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(t+1)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\theta}^{(\star)})]. This motivates us to use ∑t′=1t(1−μL)t−t′​NL​D𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆(t′)superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡superscript𝑡′𝑁𝐿superscriptsubscript𝐷𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆superscript𝑡′\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{t-t^{\prime}}\frac{N}{L}D_{\mathsf{system}}^{(t^{\prime})} as the performance metric of our proposed framework, i.e., to minimize D𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆(t)superscriptsubscript𝐷𝗌𝗒𝗌𝗍𝖾𝗆𝑡D_{\mathsf{system}}^{(t)} in Theorem 1 over {𝜷i(t)}i=1NA,{𝜶k(t)}k=1ND,𝚺V(t)superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜷𝑖𝑡𝑖1subscript𝑁𝐴superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜶𝑘𝑡𝑘1subscript𝑁𝐷superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝑡\{\bm{\beta}_{i}^{(t)}\}_{i=1}^{N_{A}},\{\bm{\alpha}_{k}^{(t)}\}_{k=1}^{N_{D}},\bm{\Sigma}_{V}^{(t)} and 𝒄(t)superscript𝒄𝑡\bm{c}^{(t)} at each round t𝑡t. (31c)

We solve the optimization problem in (31) through an iterative algorithm based on majorization-minimization (MM). The algorithm starts with a feasible point called the current-point. Each iteration round consists of two steps. In the first step, we construct a surrogate problem, whose objective serves as a lower bound of the original objective with equality holds at the current-point. Besides, the feasible region of the surrogate problem should be a subset of the original feasible region and contains the current-point. In the second step, we solve the surrogate problem, and the solution will be used as the current-point in the next iteration. Following [20], given a feasible point 𝚺V=𝚺^Vsubscript𝚺𝑉subscript^𝚺𝑉\bm{\Sigma}_{V}=\widehat{\bm{\Sigma}}_{V}, we provide a convex problem as the surrogate problem below

Since the surrogate problem (32) is convex and is solved optimally with existing convex optimization solvers such as CVXPY [23]. VI-C Optimization in Practical Design

In practical encoding and decoding function designs, 𝚺V(t)superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝑡\bm{\Sigma}_{V}^{(t)} is not an optimization variable. Therefore, the optimization of practical design is similar to the problem in (25) but does treat 𝚺V(t)superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝑡\bm{\Sigma}_{V}^{(t)} as a known constant. To estimate 𝚺V(t)superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝑡\bm{\Sigma}_{V}^{(t)}, we follow [20], to set the compression ratio σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1 for each AP and define the i𝑖i-th diagonal element of 𝚺V(t)superscriptsubscript𝚺𝑉𝑡\bm{\Sigma}_{V}^{(t)} as 1N​(𝒔i(t)−𝒖i(t))𝖳​(𝒔j(t)−𝒖j(t))1𝑁superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖𝑡𝖳superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑗𝑡\frac{1}{N}(\bm{s}_{i}^{(t)}-\bm{u}_{i}^{(t)})^{\mathsf{T}}(\bm{s}_{j}^{(t)}-\bm{u}_{j}^{(t)}). In practice, we require each AP to send a sub-vector of 𝒔i−𝒖i(t)subscript𝒔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖𝑡\bm{s}_{i}-\bm{u}_{i}^{(t)} to the CS intermittently for estimation during training.

VII Numerical Results

VII-A Experimental Settings

We validate our proposed OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework with experiments, and provide some schemes for comparison:

  • •

    Error-free bound: This bound assumes that the CS receives all the local updates of devices in an error-free fashion and updates the global model by (3).

  • •

    L-DSC bound: In our proposed OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework, this bound considers L-DSC encoding at each AP and L-DSC decoding at the CS [20]. We emphasize that the L-DSC encoding and decoding serve as a benchmark for theoretical performance limit.

  • •

    Proposed practical design: In our proposed OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework, this scheme uses the practical design proposed in Section VI as the encoding and decoding functions.

  • •

    Quantization: In our proposed OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework, this scheme is applied as follows: each AP i𝑖i computes the encoded vector 𝒖i(t)superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖𝑡\bm{u}_{i}^{(t)} as 𝒖i(t)=𝒬i(t)​(𝒔i(t),ri(t)),∀t,isuperscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒬𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑡for-all𝑡𝑖\bm{u}_{i}^{(t)}=\mathcal{Q}_{i}^{(t)}(\bm{s}_{i}^{(t)},r_{i}^{(t)}),\forall t,i, and the CS computes the global update 𝒛^(t)superscript^𝒛𝑡\hat{\bm{z}}^{(t)} as 𝒛^(t)=∑i=1NAci(t)​𝒖i(t)∈ℝN,∀tformulae-sequencesuperscript^𝒛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑖𝑡superscriptℝ𝑁for-all𝑡\hat{\bm{z}}^{(t)}=\sum_{i=1}^{N_{A}}c_{i}^{(t)}\bm{u}_{i}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{N},\forall t.

  • •

    Distributed deterministic information bottleneck (DDIB): In our proposed OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework, this scheme considers DDIB encoding at each AP and DDIB decoding at the CS, both of which are based on deep neural networks (DNN).

To make performance comparisons, we conduct federated image classification experiments on three datasets: the MNIST dataset of handwritten digits [25], the Fashion-MNIST dataset of fashion clothing [26] and the CIFAR-10 dataset. We train a neural network on each device and the CS with two 5×5555\times 5 convolution layers (the first with 101010 channels, the second with 202020, each followed by a 2×2222\times 2 max pooling operation), a fully connected layer with 50 units and ReLU activation, and a final softmax output layer (model parameter length N=21840𝑁21840N=21840). Each device performs 5 stochastic gradient descent updates with a learning rate of 0.010.010.01 and a local batch size of 1200. The CS updates the global model using a learning rate of 1.5/(1+t/10)1.51𝑡101.5/(1+t/10), where t𝑡t is the communication round. The channel gain is modeled according to [27], where the channel gain is given by 𝐇i​k(t)=GR,i​GT,k​ν​δi​k−α​𝐇~i​k(t)superscriptsubscript𝐇𝑖𝑘𝑡subscript𝐺R𝑖subscript𝐺T𝑘𝜈superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑘𝛼superscriptsubscript~𝐇𝑖𝑘𝑡\mathbf{H}_{ik}^{(t)}=\sqrt{G_{\mathrm{R},i}G_{\mathrm{T},k}\nu\delta_{ik}^{-\alpha}}\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{ik}^{(t)}. Here, the entries of 𝐇~i​k(t)superscriptsubscript~𝐇𝑖𝑘𝑡\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{ik}^{(t)} are modeled as i.i.d. circularly symmetric complex Gaussian random variables with zero-mean and unit-variance, GR,isubscript𝐺R𝑖G_{\mathrm{R},i} and GT,ksubscript𝐺T𝑘G_{\mathrm{T},k} are the antenna gains at AP i𝑖i and device k𝑘k, respectively, α𝛼\alpha is the path loss exponent, δi​ksubscript𝛿𝑖𝑘\delta_{ik} is the distance between device k𝑘k and AP i𝑖i, and ν𝜈\nu is the path loss at a reference distance of 1 m [28]. We summarize the simulation settings in Tab. I.

VII-B Comparisons of the Proposed Algorithms Under Various Settings

To verify the effectiveness of side information module in the proposed practical design, we present a comparison method called ”Proposed practical design (zero side information)”, where the side information vector 𝒔~k,i(t),∀k,i,tsuperscriptsubscript~𝒔𝑘𝑖𝑡for-all𝑘𝑖𝑡\tilde{\bm{s}}_{k,i}^{(t)},\forall k,i,t is set to 𝟎0\bm{0}. Fig. 4 shows the performance of our proposed practical design in utilizing the inter-AP correlation. The left of Fig. 4 shows the training loss of the proposed practical design, i.e., the objective in (41). The middle of Fig. 4 shows the system mean square error (MSE), i.e. ‖𝒆‖2superscriptnorm𝒆2\|\bm{e}\|^{2} versus round t𝑡t. We observe that the proposed practical design achieves lower training loss and MSE than the proposed practical design (zero side information), thanks to the ability of the side information module to leverage inter-AP correlation. Moreover, as we increased the number of layers K𝐾K, we see a decrease in both the training loss and system MSE. This improvement comes at the expense of increased computational complexity and latency, which is a reasonable trade-off. The right of Fig. 4 shows the test accuracy on MNIST dataset versus round t𝑡t. We see that by utilizing the side information module, the test accuracy of the proposed practical design was close to the L-DSC bound and the error-free bound, with a deviation of less than 1% at convergence. Additionally, the proposed practical design significantly outperformed the proposed practical design (zero side information), which further demonstrates the advantage of leveraging the inter-AP correlation.

To demonstrate the effectiveness of the optimization process in Algorithm 2, we designed three scenarios, which are depicted in the left, middle, and right sections of Fig. 5. In the first scenario, all devices have the same transmission power, and all APs have the same information rate limitation, e.g., Pk(t)=1​W,∀k,t,r~i(t)=10​ bit/symbol,∀i,tformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑡1𝑊for-all𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝑟𝑖𝑡10 bit/symbolfor-all𝑖𝑡P_{k}^{(t)}=1W,\forall k,t,\tilde{r}_{i}^{(t)}=10\text{ bit/symbol},\forall i,t. In the second scenario, devices have varying transmission power and APs have differing information rate limitations, e.g., Pk(t)=0.5superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑡0.5P_{k}^{(t)}=0.5W, ∀k∈𝒩D,1for-all𝑘subscript𝒩𝐷1\forall k\in\mathcal{N}_{D,1}, Pk(t)=1superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑡1P_{k}^{(t)}=1W ∀k∈𝒩D,2∪𝒩D,3for-all𝑘subscript𝒩𝐷2subscript𝒩𝐷3\forall k\in\mathcal{N}_{D,2}\cup\mathcal{N}_{D,3}. r1(t)=2​ bit/symbol,r2(t)=r3(t)=10​ bit/symbolformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑡2 bit/symbolsuperscriptsubscript𝑟2𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑟3𝑡10 bit/symbolr_{1}^{(t)}=2\text{ bit/symbol},r_{2}^{(t)}=r_{3}^{(t)}=10\text{ bit/symbol}. In the third scenario, we follow a similar settings as in the first scenario, but with reduced transmission power for all devices and lowered information rate limitation for all APs, e.g., Pk(t)=0.5superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑡0.5P_{k}^{(t)}=0.5W, ∀k,tfor-all𝑘𝑡\forall k,t, ri(t)=2​ bit/symbol,∀i,tsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑡2 bit/symbolfor-all𝑖𝑡r_{i}^{(t)}=2\text{ bit/symbol},\forall i,t. We also included two comparison methods, ”Proposed practical design (without optimized 𝒄𝒄\bm{c})” and ”L-DSC bound (without optimized 𝒄𝒄\bm{c})”. In these methods, the weighted parameter is fixed at 𝒄=𝟏𝒄1\bm{c}=\bm{1}. Fig. 5 shows that optimizing 𝒄𝒄\bm{c} results in a small improvement in performance in the left and right plots, but a significant improvement in the middle plot. Specifically, in the middle plot, the L-DSC bound achieves an accuracy improvement of approximately 0.017 at the convergence point, while the proposed practical design achieves an improvement of approximately 0.011. These results suggest that optimizing 𝒄𝒄\bm{c} enhance the learning performance when the communication quality across different APs is unbalanced, as in scenario (2). By examining the optimization problem of 𝒄𝒄\bm{c} in (V-D), we see that the optimization of 𝒄𝒄\bm{c} is actually a resource allocator that measures the wired communication quality of different APs to the CS and the wireless communication quality of different APs to their respective served devices. Additionally, we noted that in scenarios where the channel environment is degraded, i.e., the right plot, the test accuracy of the proposed practical design is comparable to the L-DSC bound.

To demonstrate the performance of the proposed practical design in various rate constraints, we provide Fig. 6. In this figure, we present three different rate constraint settings, as denoted by r~i(t)superscriptsubscript~𝑟𝑖𝑡\tilde{r}_{i}^{(t)}, which determine the maximum number of bits that AP i𝑖i can transmit to the CS during each training round t𝑡t. The left and middle of Fig. 4 show the training loss and MSE of proposed practical design under various rate constraints. We see that the training loss and MSE of the proposed practical design exhibit a significant increase when the rate constraint, i.e., r~i(t)superscriptsubscript~𝑟𝑖𝑡\tilde{r}_{i}^{(t)}, is close to the data dimension N𝑁N, compared to when it is close to 2​N2𝑁2N or 4​N4𝑁4N. The right of Fig. 6 compares the test accuracy of our practical design with the L-DSC bound and the error-free bound. At convergence, the accuracy of our practical design is within 0.01 of the L-DSC bound when r~i(t)superscriptsubscript~𝑟𝑖𝑡\tilde{r}_{i}^{(t)} is equal to 4​N4𝑁4N or 2​N2𝑁2N, and within 0.025 when r~i(t)superscriptsubscript~𝑟𝑖𝑡\tilde{r}_{i}^{(t)} is equal to N𝑁N.

VII-C Comparisons With Existing Schemes

We empirically validate the heterogeneous setting of federated datasets in our framework using the MNIST task. Specifically, each device randomly selects Q𝑄Q classes from the dataset {ℬk}k=1NDsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptℬ𝑘𝑘1subscript𝑁𝐷\{\mathcal{B}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{N_{D}}, and subsequently samples are randomly drawn without repetition from these selected classes. When Q𝑄Q is set to 10, the local datasets of the devices are independently and identically distributed (i.i.d.). Fig. 7 compares the test accuracy between proposed practical design and other baseline schemes under different heterogeneous settings. We observe that as the value of Q𝑄Q decreases, the learning performance of these schemes also decreases. We also see that the proposed practical design achieves a learning performance comparable to the L-DSC bound at the convergence point when Q𝑄Q is set to either 10 or 7. Furthermore, the proposed practical design outperforms the quantization scheme and the DDIB scheme across all heterogeneous settings.

VIII Conclusions

In this paper, we proposed the OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework to address the issues of limited server coverage and low resource utilization in traditional OA-FL. We also noted that inter-AP correlation can be leveraged to improve learning performance and therefore proposed modeling the global aggregation stage as an L-DSC problem to make analysis from the perspective of rate-distortion theory. We further analyzed the performance of the proposed OA-FL in MIMO Cloud-RAN framework. Based on this analysis, we formulated a communication-learning optimization problem to improve the system performance by considering the inter-AP correlation. We showed that, under mild conditions, the problem can be solved using alternating optimization (AO) and majorization-minimization (MM). Subsequently, we proposed a practical design that demonstrates the utilization of inter-AP correlation. The numerical results show that the proposed practical design effectively leverages inter-AP correlation, and outperforms other baseline schemes.

by using the triangle inequality and the inequality of arithmetic means. With (6), (9)-(10), (18), we have

(44)

From the assumption in Lemma 2, we have
